Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Engineering Identity, its Predictors, and its Impact on Retention across Educational Stages

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports persistence in engineering by understanding how identity develops in high school, undergraduate, and graduate students, and how it may develop differently for underrepresented students. Identity refers to how people see themselves, or the "kind of person" that they identify with. Logically speaking, if individuals strongly identify themselves with a particular field, they are more likely to pursue and remain in that field. Yet there is limited research testing this idea, particularly in engineering. This project is surveying thousands of students in engineering programs at a variety of different high schools and colleges to build an evidence base. The results are being used to understand how engineering identity and early engineering experiences predict persistence to graduation and persistence in the profession. This information is being used to better design and evaluate the impact of early engineering outreach and interventions. The variety of schools and students in this study is enabling examination of differences by gender and ethnicity, which is informing interventions to broaden participation of underrepresented groups in engineering. The results are being disseminated widely to teachers, professors, administrators and others so that they can use the results to improve programs for engineering student recruitment and retention.

The investigators are employing survey scale development and multivariate regression modeling to examine the predictors of engineering identity and its impact on persistence at different educational stages. Identity is emerging as an attractive explanation for who persists in engineering, yet few studies have directly linked identity to persistence, nor thoroughly examined the host of factors that shape identity. This project is building on work on math and science identity, as well as research on the importance of professional experiences, to examine these issues. The study is unique in its examination of engineering identity across a range of educational stages, including high school, undergraduate, graduate, and recent bachelor's-level engineering graduates. Through ongoing longitudinal work and a cross-sectional design using multivariate regression, this study is describing engineering identity trajectories from high school through graduate study or professional employment. Study sites include 100 high schools enrolling approximately 5000 students per year in engineering courses and engineering departments of mechanical, civil and biomedical engineering at five institutions enrolling a total of 5000 undergraduate and 2000 graduate engineering students. The results are providing an understanding of how engineering identity develops and how that identity impacts persistence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The extent to which engineering students hold strong beliefs about themselves as related to engineering has a significant impact on their future career plans, and therefore a significant impact on retention of engineers in education and the workforce.

 

Intellectual Merit: As part of this project, we investigated the persistence of undergraduate engineering students based on their beliefs about their ability to perform engineering tasks, their confidence in engineering tasks, interest in engineering, and recognition by friends and family as engineers. We found that persistence (i.e., remaining in an undergraduate engineering program for one year) was primarily due to interest in learning more about engineering. In fact, some of the other beliefs are weakened over time as individual students experience engineering undergraduate training.

 

For graduate students, we applied similar ideas to measure identity beliefs related to engineering and research. We confirmed that beliefs about ability, confidence, interest and recognition by others are relevant at the graduate level. Further, we found that milestones such as earning an engineering bachelor's degree and publishing a journal article are important for identity development in graduate students. Beliefs about research identity and engineering identity predict whether students are interested in employment in academic, government or industry jobs–with the majority of graduate students considering multiple career options at the same time. We uncovered some differences in employment based on experiences with internships, citizenship status and engineering discipline.

 

Building on these findings, we also developed new ways to measure engineering identity through questionnaires. Working from a list developed by engineering accreditation agencies, we interviewed engineering students and professionals to identify key elements of engineering practice. We developed survey items and used statistical analysis to measure six distinct elements of engineering professional practice: 1) framing and solving problems, 2) design, 3) project management, 4) analysis, 5) collaboration, and 6) tinkering. Additionally, we explored and developed a new way of assessing the overlap between one’s personal identity and the identity of an engineering professional. With these new ways to measure engineering identity and practices, we investigated a) gender differences in identity and engineering practices, b) gender differences in identity, beliefs and career plans for in biomedical engineering (a discipline with nearly as many women as men), and c) changes in students’ identity and beliefs over time.

 

We found gender differences in engineering identity for undergraduate engineering students at UT Austin. For female students, there is a stronger relationship between engineering identity and enjoying framing and solving problems. For the biomedical engineering students, there were no gender differences in their intended career plans after graduation. Yet, men rated their confidence in engineering tasks, interest in engineering and identity as an engineer higher than women.

 

For undergraduate students, we found differences in change of beliefs over a one year period. For first and second year undergraduates, we found significant decreases in beliefs about the usefulness of engineering to their goals, engineering confidence, and engineering interest. We also found significant decreases in wanting to be good at engineering for third and fourth year students. In terms of gender differences, among third and fourth year students, men's confidence in engineering was higher than women's.

 

With our collaborators, we also explored the differences in engineering identity and the desire to pursue engineering as a job among Latinx students. In comparing two Texas institutions, we found that Latinx students at the established Hispanic-Serving Institution had a stronger engineering identity, greater interest in engineering, and stronger desire to work in an engineering job after graduation. We expanded the study to 7 Hispanic-Serving Institutions in four states. There are few differences by institution, and the data set is uniquely large enough to compare identity and career plans between Latinx and non-Latinx engineering student populations. In particular, the elements of engineering professional practice (listed above) are more influential in Latinx students' future career plans than for non-Latinx students.

 

Broader Impacts: Ultimately, this work has helped bring additional insight into the myriad factors that contribute to students' engineering identity development, particularly of Latinx students. It has produced new ways of thinking about identity and retention of engineering students and created and tested new scales that others are using to evaluate interventions. Further, we were able to bring together a network of faculty from eight Hispanic-Serving Institutions and, for several of them, introduce them to engineering education research for the first time.
